Message.Title: Old fashioned "Bear Raid"
Message.Msg: With another downgrade of INTC, the Bears have ONE last chance to try to hold NDVA down, and they're trying an old fashioned "Bear Raid" by pounding the stock hard with reasonable volume to start the day. Given the way the stock closed, Thursday, the Bears are now desperate and I do not believe they will be successful at keeping the stock down. So, look for a recovery throughout the day, and then we'll see what happens in The Final Hour. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Max

Message.Title: INTC: JMP cuts to hold on rumored "Haswell" power circuitry issues
Message.Msg: SOURCE: BARROHS just in barronsDOTcom/techtraderdaily/2013/04/01/intel-jmp-cuts-to-hold-on-rumored-haswell-power-circuitry-issues/ Part 1: ""The Intel effort to integrate a voltage regulation (VR) stage into the Haswell architecture appears to have fallen short of desired results, and the company is consequently reversing course and not pursuing this power management scheme with subsequent products. Our discovery of this issue came from discussions with multiple power management partners at the APEC (Applied Power Electronics Conference) trade show that was held March 17-21, 2013, and we were also informed that they had only just become aware of Intel’s change of direction in prior weeks. To be clear, the industry sources we spoke with indicated Haswell is working, but that “the new power approach did not live up to expectations.” It was the consensus view that timelines were also slipping, both for the Haswell refresh for PCs in 2H13 and likely down the road for the next two-socket Xeon server move to Haswell that is known as Grantley and expected in 2H14 […] Sources declined to elaborate on (or didn‟t know) the exact performance implications; however, integrated VR was touted as a key feature that will afford the Haswell platform improved power efficiency without compromising performance. We also know from speaking with senior Intel engineers that integrated VR had been “an area of great debate internally.” It seems evident at this juncture that this debate was won by integration proponents, but then lost in terms of benefit yield.""

Topic.Title: INTC: JMP cuts to hold on rumored "Haswell" power circuitry issues

Message.Msg: Part 2: "It was the consensus view that timelines were also slipping, both for the Haswell refresh for PCs in 2H13 and likely down the road for the next two-socket Xeon server move to Haswell that is known as Grantley and expected in 2H14."" ""The unfortunate thing for Intel is that overall computing demand appears generally healthy. The demand, however, is heavily skewed toward tablets and smartphones where Intel has yet to establish a material presence. Intel has been able to make only modest progress in smartphones and tablets to date, and there was no evidence out of the 2013 CES or Mobile World Congress trade shows to suggest this is likely to change this year."" ""We expect 2014 gross margins to be weighed upon by under-absorbed capital spending expenses, and operating margins to be impacted by ongoing levels of elevated spending as Intel continues to pound away on its mobile initiatives in smartphones and tablets."" _______ JMP analyst comments in quotes.

Topic.Title: INTC: JMP cuts to hold on rumored "Haswell" power circuitry issues

Message.Msg: Ouch "The demand, however, is heavily skewed toward tablets and smartphones where Intel has yet to establish a material presence. Intel has been able to make only modest progress in smartphones and tablets to date, and there was no evidence out of the 2013 CES or Mobile World Congress trade shows to suggest this is likely to change this year." Should quiet the INTC bulls, and certainly gives the ARM camp more runway.

Message.Msg: J seven packs: I will give you a last free lesson in options. Savvy option players sell puts (which is synthetic call) at market bottom or s stock's intermediate low - which is what NVDA is at now. I don't write NVDA near monthd (strike 13) calls because the low premiums don't interest me - you probably got 10 cents or 15 for the calls you wrote - these are peanuts to me, not worth bothering and exposing my large position to. Your question comes from typically someone who doesn't know anything about options. I do hope you will get it eventually. Read a good book on options strategy and don't commit your retirement nest eggs to this game. AND look up NVDA near months 12/13 puts and pay attention to the premium. You do need a much higher level of clearance before being granted the privilege to sell puts (which I suspect you might not qualify). So...what is after INTC?

Message.Title: Intel approached Nvidia's CEO
Message.Msg: It’s an unlikely thing, we know, but we don’t do April Fool’s jokes. Sources at Intel Santa Clara have assured us that the CEO of Nvidia, Jen-Hsen Huang was approached by headhunters seeking for a replacement for Paul Otellini, who stands down at the chip giant at the end of May. Jen-Hsen, who worked for AMD in a former incarnation, is on record as saying that if he worked for Intel it would only be as the head of the corporation. Noted for his incredible work ethic, Jen-Hsen built Nvidia up more or less from scratch. But its unclear how far the approaches went – Intel’s head hunters are more or less scrabbling around trying to find the successor for Otellini. Pat Gelsinger, chief technology officer at EMC, has signalled that he’s not interested in the job. Internal candidates include Dadi Perlmutter. The future CEO of Intel, whoever she or he is, faces a daunting task. Faced with the fact of convergence and people moving in droves to use smartphones and tablets without any X86 device inside, Intel, basically, needs to be completely re-engineered.

Message.Title: " Nvidia is bitter about PlayStation 4, says AMD"
Message.Msg: "When asked about Nvidia's Tony Tamasi's statement back in March, which stated that the PlayStation 4's speccs were comparable to a low-end CPU, Robinson said, "Well, of course they're going to do that. They're a little bitter." Sony has made it official. The PS4 does, in fact, exist AMD gave Sony the hardware Nvidia couldn't He continued, "For us, really by looking at that APU that we designed, you can't pull out individual components off it and hold it up and say, 'Yeah, this compares to X or Y'." "It's that integration of the two, and especially with the amount of shared memory [8GB of GDDR5, 176GB/s raw memory bandwidth] that Sony has chosen to put on that machine, then you're going to be able to do so much more moving and sharing that data that you can address by both sides. It's more than just a CPU doing all these amazing calculations and a GPU doing calculations. We are now going to be able to move certain tasks between the two." " Source: Tech2

Topic.Title: Intel Haswell is NOT WELL and never was well should be called a Hasbeen

Message.Msg: April 1, 2013, 2:47 P.M. ET Intel Rebuffs JMP Warning About ‘Haswell’; ‘On Track and On Time’ By Tiernan Ray Following a downgrade this morning of Intel (INTC) shares to Market Perform from Outperform by Alex Gauna of JMP Securities, based on speculation by Gauna that the chip maker may be at risk of delays in its forthcoming microprocessor upgrade, code-named “Haswell, Intel spokesperson Chuck Mulloy reached out to tech trader to assert there are no issues. Said Mulloy in a phone call, Haswell is healthy and on track for an announcement. There’s no problem with the Haswell part at all. Also, we would expect that with Haswell we will see the biggest improvement in battery life in the company’s history when you compare it to the previous generation. It is expected to be a major milestone breakthrough. The key point is, it’s healthy and it’s on time Said Mulloy in a phone call, Haswell is healthy and on track for an announcement. There’s no problem with the Haswell part at all. Also, we would expect that with Haswell we will see the biggest improvement in battery life in the company’s history when you compare it to the previous generation. It is expected to be a major milestone breakthrough. The key point is, it’s healthy and it’s on time. Mulloy was referring to previous remarks about Haswell made by management during the company’s January Q4 conference call. At that time, the company said “We started production on Haswell, which we expect to qualify for sale this quarter [Q1] [...] This resulted in an increase in inventory write-offs [in Q4]. We expect to be production-ready in the current quarter.” The remark about record improvements in power efficiency were consistent with previous promises by Intel regarding Haswell, said Mulloy.

Message.Title: What is holdup with Samsung Exynos 5 Octa? (Only 30% of S4 will be powered by the Exynos Octa(
Message.Msg: Why the Exynos 5 Octa chip so scarce? "What's the holdup? Well, it turns out that Samsung went with the simpler and cheaper way to design 28nm chips like the Exynos 5 Octa, called gate-first, while the competing foundry TSMC designed its production capacity with the harder to implement gate-last process, developed by Intel. The problem stems from the fact that gate-first might be easier to transition to, but gives yield problems later on, especially with complex SoCs, and that's exactly what seems to be happening with Exynos 5 Octa. "" SOURCE: phonearenaDOTcom/news/Whats-the-holdup-with-Samsung-Galaxy-S4s-Exynos-5-Octa-version_id41408?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+phonearena%2FySoL+(Phone+Arena+-+Latest+News) TSMC (where all NVDA's parts are fabricated) started the 28nm with gate-first HKMG, but transitioned successfully to the gate-last process by the end of 2012 according to SemiWiKi: semiwikiDOTcom/forum/content/1904-tsmc-28nm-20nm-update-q4-2012.html

Message.Title: JH Interview
Message.Msg: It would be pretty stupid to think Intel is not prepared to hear what JH has to say about combining the 2 companies and how it would work. It would be even more stupid to think JH has not thought about how it would work out or what his strategy would be should he run the two companies 1. HPC & Servers - Grow the X86GPU & GPU Grid Servers. Create new line of ArmGPU servers for low to mid end. 2. Embed Nvidia GPUs in X86 to lower cost and increase performance for low to mid end APUs 3. Embed Nvidia GPUs in Atom for X86 Tablet platforms for lower cost and better performance 4. Battle high end Phone (Arm+Icera) & Tablet markets (Arm) using latest process technology. 5. Battle mainstream and cost sensitive mobile markets with under utilize older process technologies (Intel is a process node ahead of others). 6. Continue advance GPU development to drive everything. I don't see how they can loose to anybody.

Topic.Title: JH Interview

Message.Msg: In the Mobile World The GPU is the CENTER of the universe NOT the CPU. Intel is in trouble because their architecture is CPU centric and occupies too much real estate! By the time they add a competitive GPU they become BLOAT WARE! And to make it manufacturable - they have to waste their latest technology just to be competitive instead of leaping ahead. Look at T4 - only ~ 30% of it is the CPUs - the rest is the GPU!

Topic.Title: JH Interview

Message.Msg: I don't think jen can actually be the CEO of its biggest competitor without merging the companies together. With his product knowledge of nvidia's roadmap, it would be a problem for all the shareholders who would cry foul. I don't think Jen wants to go to Intel. I think he wants to kick intels #$%$ instead. He is p#$%$ionate about nvidia and plenty rich. Why does he want to go to intel when they have no mobile strategy. If the companies merge then it could be interesting but i can't see it happening any other way

Message.Title: 1000 dollar Titan boards still selling out after a month
Message.Msg: Hey guys...anybody else notice that there seems to be pretty healthy demand for $1000 graphic cards. The titan was introduced at the end of February and more than a month later, they sell out as soon as more stock comes in. Thats pretty amazing. Margins on this product must be very good. If nvidia can move a lot of these boards in the short term, it will boost earnings. Remember that their quarter still has another month. If they sell like 50k of these, it adds 50 million to the revenue and about 30 million to the profit. Based on the constant inventory evaporation, there seems to be significant demand for these cards. Could be a very interesting report early next month. There are over 1 billion pc gamers out there...get 50k of them to buy this board should be no problem...If they sell more than that, we are really going to crush the numbers. I think nvidia thought this would be a niche product but to me seems like demand is higher than they expected.
